prompt.p: A 59-year-old man complains of increasing dyspnoea over 18 months and an itchy, painful rash over the legs and ankles. On examination, there is parotid gland enlargement and hepatosplenomegaly. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Serum calcium is 2.8 mmol/L (normal range 2.1â€“2.6 mmol/L).
What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option D (Sarcoidosis) is Correct. Sarcoidosis has hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray and/or parenchymal lung shadowing. Hypercalcaemia is due to macrophage production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D.
Option A (Hyperparathyroidism) is Incorrect. Hypercalcaemia is not associated with organomegaly or chest X-ray signs.

Option B (Multiple myeloma) is Incorrect. Multiple myeloma X-ray changes in long bones would be more in keeping with this diagnosis (lytic lesions). Lung parenchymal changes on chest X-ray are more indicative of a different pathology.

Option C (Paget's disease) is Incorrect. This is indicated by frontal bossing, deafness and cranial nerve palsies due to uncontrolled bone turnover. Pathological fractures and platybasia are complications. Hypercalcaemia is not usually present
Option E (Squamous cell carcinoma) is Incorrect. This patient has symptoms of lung carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma has ectopic parathyroid hormone related protein that causes hypercalcaemia.
